name: Singular cardinal
explained: The Singular Cardinal Conjecture (SCC) is a significant hypothesis in set theory concerning the behavior of singular cardinals. It states that if \( \kappa \) is a singular cardinal and \( \cf(\kappa) = \lambda \) (the cofinality of \( \kappa \) is \( \lambda \)), then the SCH (singular cardinals hypothesis) holds for \( \kappa \), i.e., \( 2^{\kappa} = \kappa^{++} \), where \( \kappa^{++} \) is the second successor cardinal after \( \kappa \). In other words, the power set of \( \kappa \) has the same cardinality as the \( \aleph \)-number immediately following the \( \aleph \)-number of \( \kappa \)'s cofinality.
